hints_html:
How do we solve

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{x}=\lambda\mathbf{x}\end{aligned}\]

for x with a given \(\lambda\)?
hints_raw:
How do we solve

:<math>
A\mathbf{x}=\lambda\mathbf{x}
</math>

for '''x''' with a given <math>\lambda</math>?
question: B 05 (a)
sols_html:
We want to solve something of the form

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{x}&=\lambda\mathbf{x} (A-\lambda{}I)\mathbf{x}&=\mathbf{0}\end{aligned}\]

where I is the identity matrix. In this case we have \(\lambda_1=1\) so we have that

\[\begin{aligned} A-\lambda_1I=A-I= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & -3\\ -1 & -1 & 2\\ 1 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

To solve (A-I)x we write x=[a,b,c] and solve

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 & -3\\ -1 & -1 & 2\\ 1 & 0 & -1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} a\\ b\\ c \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which is equivalent to solving

\[\begin{aligned} 2a+b-3c&=0,\\ -a-b+2c&=0,\\ a-c&=0.\end{aligned}\]

This has solution b=c=a for any arbitrary a. Therefore we take a=1, without loss of generality, and our eigenvetor is

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
statement_html:
Consider the matrix below:

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 1 & -3\\ -1 & 0 & 2\\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

It is known that \(\lambda_1=1\) is an eigenvalue of A.

Find an eigenvector associated with the eigenvalue \(\lambda_1 = 1\).
